talk.utter: Do we know what the rate of false negatives on the rapid tests is? I've gotten a bunch of negative results when PCR confirmed I had it, but that was earlier in the pandemic.

talk.utter: Just shy of 20%, depending on how long it's been since exposure. That's also why a lot of kits have two tests, so you can repeat if you had a negative result on the first go.

talk.author: did:plc:cpa5rqgymyuv7r5yi5dp5xcv

talk.author: did:plc:lqkheqydiacwfpygdcazbg76
talk.utter:
There's two components that go into accuracy: sensitivity and specificity.
Maximizing one tends to destroy the other, so the achievable ideal is one that balances both.
With this test, a positive result is much more accurate than a negative result, and repeating negatives minimizes that risk.

talk.author: did:plc:cpa5rqgymyuv7r5yi5dp5xcv
talk.utter: Cool! So should we take a second test right after the first negative? I was told to wait 48 and try again (while isolating in the meantime), but this sounds nonsensical now.
